description:
Shinisaurus crocodilurus, commonly known as the Chinese crocodile lizard, is a unique species of lizard found in southeastern China and northern Vietnam. It belongs to the family Shinisauridae, which is the only surviving family in the order Shinisauria.

The Chinese crocodile lizard is a small, semi-aquatic reptile with a distinctive appearance. It has a flattened, crocodile-like head and body, with a long, muscular tail that it uses for swimming. Its scales are rough and overlapping, providing protection and helping it blend in with its aquatic environment.

These lizards are known for their ability to remain submerged in water for extended periods, allowing them to hunt for small fish, amphibians, and invertebrates. They are capable of both terrestrial and aquatic locomotion, using their strong limbs and tail to navigate their complex habitat.

Shinisaurus crocodilurus is considered a vulnerable species due to habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as illegal collection for the pet trade. Conservation efforts are underway to protect this unique and fascinating reptile, which serves as an important indicator of the health of its delicate wetland ecosystem.
